title: 110_hr3648
content: The "Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007" excludes discharges of indebtedness on a principal residence from gross income. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness discharged before January 1, 2010 from gross income. Additionally, the amount excluded from gross income reduces the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income, reducing the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. Subsection (a)(1)(E) applies to reduce the basis of the principal residence, with exceptions for certain discharges not related to the taxpayer's financial condition. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income, reducing the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. Subsection (a)(1)(E) applies to reduce the basis of the principal residence, with exceptions for certain discharges not related to the taxpayer's financial condition. The ordering rule states that if a loan is discharged, only the portion exceeding the non-qualified principal residence indebtedness is subject to the exclusion. The amendments made by this section apply to discharges of indebtedness on or after January 1, 2007, with changes to the principal residence exclusion and insolvency exclusion. SEC. 3 extends the treatment of mortgage insurance premiums as interest until December 31, 2010. SEC. 4 provides alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation. SEC. 4 amends the definition of a cooperative housing corporation in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifying requirements related to gross income, property usage, and expenditures for the taxable year. The amendment to the definition of a cooperative housing corporation in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 requires that 90 percent or more of expenditures are for property benefitting tenant-stockholders. This amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION FROM INCOME FOR BENEFITS PROVIDED TO VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL RESPONDERS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section, SEC. 139B, which excludes benefits provided to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders from gross income. In the case of qualified volunteer emergency response organization members, gross income excludes qualified State and local tax benefits and qualified payments. Deductions and expenses for services are limited to avoid double benefits. Definitions include qualified state and local tax benefits. The term 'qualified state and local tax benefit' refers to tax reductions provided by a State for services as a member of a volunteer emergency response organization. 'Qualified payment' is any payment for such services, limited to $30 per month. The section limits the tax reduction for volunteer emergency responders to $30 per month, based on the number of months of service. It defines a qualified organization as one providing firefighting or emergency medical services and required by a written agreement to do so. This provision expires after December 31, 2010. The tax reduction for volunteer emergency responders is limited to $30 per month based on service months. A qualified organization provides firefighting or emergency medical services. This provision expires after December 31, 2010. This section does not apply to taxable years after December 31, 2010. The tax reduction for volunteer emergency responders is limited to $30 per month based on service months and applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. Additionally, there is a clarification regarding student housing eligible for low-income housing credit. The amendment made by this section applies to housing credit amounts allocated and buildings placed in service before or after the enactment date. Additionally, the joint return limitation for capital gains exclusion is applied to certain post-marriage sales of principal residences by surviving spouses. SEC. 7. APPLICATION OF JOINT RETURN LIMITATION FOR CAPITAL GAINS EXCLUSION TO CERTAIN POST-MARRIAGE SALES OF PRINCIPAL RESIDENCES BY SURVIVING SPOUSES. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows surviving spouses to substitute $500,000 for $250,000 in the joint return limitation for capital gains exclusion if the sale occurs within 2 years of the spouse's death. Effective for sales after December 31, 2007. SEC. 8. MODIFICATION OF PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO FILE PARTNERSHIP RETURNS; LIMITATION ON DISCLOSURE. Extension of Time Limitation for filing partnership returns is increased from 5 months to 12 months. Penalty amount for failure to file partnership returns is raised from $50 to $85. Limitation on disclosure of taxpayer returns to partners, S corporation shareholders, trust beneficiaries, and estate beneficiaries is amended under section 6103(e) of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment regarding the disclosure of taxpayer information from partnerships, S corporations, trusts, or estates will not include details of individuals other than those filing the return or involved in the inspection. The effective date of this amendment is the enactment date of the Act. SEC. 9. PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO FILE S CORPORATION RETURNS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a penalty for failure to file S Corporation returns. SEC. 9. PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO FILE S CORPORATION RETURNS. S corporations failing to file returns under section 6037 will incur a penalty of $85 per month per shareholder for up to 12 months, unless reasonable cause is shown. The penalty for failure to file S corporation returns is $85 per month per shareholder for up to 12 months, assessed against the S corporation. Deficiency procedures do not apply for the assessment or collection of this penalty. The penalty for failure to file S corporation returns is $85 per month per shareholder for up to 12 months, assessed against the S corporation. The amendments made by this section apply to returns required to be filed after the date of the enactment of this Act. The percentage under subparagraph (B) of section 401(1) of the Tax Increase Prevention and Reconciliation Act of 2005 is increased by 1.50 percentage points.
